response.apiMessage: This XML was provided by Springer Nature

title-group.article-title: Mixed convective flow of an Oldroyd-B nanofluid impinging over an unsteady bidirectional stretching surface with the significances of double stratification and chemical reaction

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: The numerous applications of non-Newtonian nanofluids in engineering, geothermal and industrial processes motivated us to formulate a comprehensive model for unsteady 3D flow of an Oldroyd-B nanomaterial. Brownian motion and thermophoresis characteristics are also accommodated through a Buongiorno nanofluid model. Moreover, assessments of thermal stratification, chemical reaction, solutal stratification, mixed convection, and prescribed heat source are also elucidated in the combinations of momentum, energy, and concentration equations. The transformed system of ODEs is tackled by homotopy analysis method. A comparison benchmark for limited cases is also constructed to confirm the correctness of whole parametric exploration. It is scrutinized through present communication that intensifying values of Prandtl factor, unsteady factor, heat distribution indices, thermal stratification constraint, mixed convective parameter, and Deborah number for time retardation diminish the temperature of the nanomaterial. Also, escalating amounts of Lewis number, chemically reactive species, Brownian motion parameter, and solutal stratification constraint reduce the concentration profile.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the current century, the development of human society extremely depends upon nanotechnology. Nanofluid plays a fundamental role in the development of industrial sector. A new variety of energy transport fluid is well-known as nanomaterial, which is basically the mixture of base fluid and nanoparticles. Higher thermal conductivity is the basic requirement of many industrial and engineering applications. Thermal enactment of heat carrying liquid can be increased by submerging the nanoparticles into the base fluids. These supremacies of nanomaterials make them applicable in several progressions of heat transport like microelectronics, fuel cells, heat exchangers system, hybrid powered engines, refrigeration, cooling chambers, etc. In past few decades, various nanofluid models have been utilized to upturn the thermal conductivity of the materials but special preference is given to Buongiorno model [1]. In Buongiorno’s model, the special characteristics of Brownian motion and thermophoresis are utilized to meet the requirements of industrial and engineering sectors. Applications of nanofluids in solar water heating, engine cooling, coolings of transformer oil and electronics, improving heat transport efficiency of chillers, in nuclear reactor, and defense, etc. are explained by Saidur et al. [2]. Gireesha et al. [3] presented a numerical exploration on influence of suspended nanoparticles on boundary regime flow and heat transport aspects of a nanoliquid immersed in a porous space over a stretchable surface. The influences of Brownian motion and thermophoresis characteristics are scrutinized by Khan et al. [4] in the flows of nanomaterial impinging on an expandable surface, numerically. Khan et al. [5] also scrutinized the nanofluid flow upon a linear porous bi-directionally stretchable surface. Hayat et al. [6] explored the study of nanofluid flow due to bi-directionally expandable surface depending on heat and mass fluxes restrictions. Recently, Ahmad et al. [7] illustrated the time-dependent nanofluid flow impinging on a bi-directionally extendable surface with adjustable heat mechanism. Ahmad et al. [8] also scrutinized the nanofluid flow impinging on an unsteady bi-directionally extendable surface with predefined surface temperature and predefined surface heat flux in the consequence of Cattaneo–Christov double diffusion. Some latest contributions in this direction are also made by many investigators [9–15] under various aspects of nanofluid flow phenomenas.

The energy conversion problems of Oldroyd-B nanoliquid flow due to stretchable surface have dominant role in the engineering, and industrial processes. Contribution of these materials arises in extrusion of polymer sheet, condensation processes, resonance imaging, heat exchanger devices, and many more. Khan et al. [16] illustrated the Oldroyd-B nanomaterial flow impinging on a bi-directionally stretchable obstacle with internal heat generator/absorber. After that, Hayat et al. [17] scrutinized the flow of an Oldroyd-B nanomaterial over a linearly bi-directionally extendable surface with the significance of magnetic coating, analytically. The influence of thermophoresis mechanism on an unsteady Oldroyd-B nanomaterial flow impinging on a linearly stretchable obstacle is critically analyzed by Awad et al. [18]. The influence of variable thermal conductivity on the flow of an Oldroyd-B nanoliquid impinging on an unsteady stretchable obstacle is investigated by Motsa and Ansari [19]. Radiative flow of an Oldroyd-B nanoliquid impinging on a stretchable obstacle is analytically analyzed by Hayat et al. [20]. Flow plus heat transport of an Oldroyd-B nanoliquid impinging on an unsteady stretchable obstacle are investigated by Zhang et al. [21]. Stagnated flow of an Oldroyd-B nanoliquid towards an unsteady stretchable obstacle with the performances of mixed convection, convective conditions, and thermal radiation is explained by Hayat et al. [22]. Shehzad et al. [23] explored the bi-directional stretched Oldroyd-B nanomaterial impinging on a radiative obstacle with the characteristic of magnetite field. An analytical attempt is made by Hayat et al. [24] to explore the Oldroyd-B nanoliquid flow induced by a stretchable surface with the performance of internal heat generator/absorber. DTM-Padé solution for bi-directional flow of an Oldroyd-B nanoliquid due to a linearly stretchable obstacle is scrutinized by Gupta et al. [25].

Stratification is a conventional phenomenon which arises due to the presence of different liquids with different densities, variation in temperatures differences, or changes in concentration differences. This type of phenomenon is extremely used in geophysical flows and attains a considerably height in recent years. Such flows can be seen in ground water reservoirs system, thermal energy storage devices, rivers and seas, and lakes, etc. Hussain et al. [26] studied the performance of double stratification in mixed convective flow of Maxwell nanoliquid impinging on a radiative stretchable obstacle. The enactments of mixed convection and internal heat generator/absorber on double stratified flow of Maxwell nanomaterial impinging on a linearly stretchable obstacle are analyzed by Abbasi et al. [27]. Waqas et al. [28] described the flow of an Oldroyd-B nanoliquid with the characteristics of stratification and internal heat generator over an expandable surface. Hayat et al. [29] also analyzed the influences of thermal and solutal stratifications in mixed convective Oldroyd-B nanomaterial flow impinging on a steady bi-directionally expandable obstacle with chemical reaction. Hashmi et al. [30] illustrated the mixed convection flow of an Oldroyd-B nanoliquid generated by stretchable disk with the influence of magnetic environment. The study of an Oldroyd-B nanoliquid flow impinging on a stretchable obstacle is carried out by many investigators [31–35] under the influences of Brownian motion, thermophoresis, heat generator/absorber, and chemically reacted species. Some more extraordinary explorations about the advancements in the flows of nanofluid are explored by the investigators [36–45].

In the view of over-head literature cited, it is noted that there exist a slab for the investigation of mixed convective flow of an Oldroyd-B nanofluid impinging on an unsteady bi-directionally expandable surface. Moreover, the performances of chemical reaction, solutal stratification, thermal stratification, Brownian motion, and thermophoresis are also incorporated. The novel characteristic of this exploration is that we considered the unsteady flow of an Oldroyd-B nanomaterial with the prescribed distribution of heat, which is not reported previously to the best of our information. Boundary layer approximations are used to reshape the modeled equations of bidirectional flow of an Oldroyd-B nanofluid before transforming into dimensionless forms. Furthermore, analytical solution of dimensionless system of non-linear ODEs is made by employing homotopy analysis method (HAM) [46–49]. Impressions of sundry parameters on temperature and nanoparticles concentration distributions are plotted and discussed carefully. It is expected that this marvelous addition in the field of non-Newtonian nanofluid flow will not only attract its readers but also will be a wonderful spectrum for future endeavors.

Method for solution
Convergence analysis
Results and discussion
Thermal and concentration profiles
Heat and mass transports
Conclusion
Conflict of interest
sec.p: The corresponding author (M. Faisal) states that there is no conflict of interest.
